payload.title: Arriving at Suvarnabhumi (BKK)
payload.description: BKK is massive. After clearing immigration, you must descend to **Level B** for trains or **Level 1** for taxis. Avoid the touts on the arrival floor.
payload.criticalAlert: Only use the **Official Taxi Kiosks** on Level 1. Do not accept rides from 'limousine' touts inside the terminal; they cost 3x more.
tips: **Airport Rail Link:** Follow signs to the basement (Level B). It connects directly to the MRT (Phetchaburi) and BTS (Phaya Thai).
**Taxi Kiosks:** Press the button for a ticket (Small/Large/Short distance) and go to the assigned lane number.
**Highway Tolls:** Drivers will ask for cash (25฿–50฿) at the toll booths. This is normal and expected.
**Sim Cards:** Buy your eSim or physical card at the AIS or DTAC booths *after* customs for the best local rates.

payload.title: Cash & ATM Strategy
payload.description: Thailand is the land of the **flat 220฿ ATM fee**. Cards work in malls (7-Eleven has a 200฿ minimum), but street food is cash-only.
payload.criticalAlert: Every ATM withdrawal costs **220฿ (~$6)** regardless of the amount. Withdraw the maximum (usually 20,000฿–30,000฿) to minimize fees.
tips: **SuperRich:** For the best rates, look for the 'Orange' or 'Green' SuperRich booths, especially the one in the Airport Rail Link basement.
**No DCC:** When using a card, always choose **'Pay in Local Currency (THB)'**. Never let the machine do the conversion.
**Coins:** Keep 10฿ coins for laundry machines and older bus conductors.

payload.title: Scams & Safety
payload.description: Bangkok is generally very safe, but 'The Grand Palace is closed' is the oldest trick in the book.
payload.criticalAlert: If a well-dressed local or tuk-tuk driver tells you a landmark is closed for a 'Buddhist Holiday,' **ignore them**. They are trying to take you to a jewelry store.
tips: **Metered Taxis:** If the driver refuses the meter, get out. There are thousands of taxis; the next one will use it.
**Dress Code:** Temples require covered shoulders and knees. Carry a light sarong in your bag.
**Grab App:** Use Grab to see the 'fair price' for a route before negotiating with a street taxi or tuk-tuk.
